I wouldnâ€™t call it the *worst* disorder, personally, because I donâ€™t know what people with other personality disorders go through. 

I do know that when Iâ€™m in one of these states (is there a name for it? dissociation?) itâ€™s best for me to shut off from everyone and write in my journal like a madwoman. One of the main issues for me is the climate crisis. Education has no use if the global temperature rises to a point where we would face mass extinction (which is what the data is predicting). Budgets are pointless if ecosystems are dying. Unfortunately no one has really discussed this, not even Green Party members. Jagmeet Singh *just* today made a statement on climate change. Iâ€™m trying to remain optimistic but it all seems quite dismal. I hope thereâ€™s more discourse on this issue as we get closer to the election.

â€œHigh performingâ€? I take it you have never taught in Asia or even taught any students from East Asia. This is a whole other issue that we shouldnâ€™t even get into here: these kids can pass tests, sure, but many of them lack any sort of real comprehension. Iâ€™ve had students come into my high intermediate level English class and not be able to speak a word of English (literally). I would not call that â€œhigh performing,â€ would you? 

I do agree with you on the making choices bit. Everyone needs to be held accountable for their actions. I just think we should have a little more empathy for the â€œproblemâ€ kids.

But maybe you guys in the States are frustrated because the government and society doesnâ€™t respect the profession of teaching at all. Here in Canada we are  compensated quite well (despite recent budget cuts), so I think itâ€™s our responsibility to do everything we can to do our job well.

Why arenâ€™t we asking WHY theyâ€™re â€œproblematicâ€? What systemic barriers are in place that may be preventing them from learning?

I work in an inner city school and many â€œproblemâ€ students are: modeling what they see at home; expressing frustration or other emotions they canâ€™t articulate otherwise; trying to create distractions so they wonâ€™t have to admit their reading level (for example) is far below that of their peers... the list goes on. 

Instead of demonizing â€œproblemâ€ students, we need to remember they are CHILDREN. There are always reasons for misbehaviour in class. Itâ€™s extremely tough to get to the point where a child feels safe to share with you whatâ€™s going on in their life, but your teaching and their learning improve tenfold when they do.

I couldnâ€™t say, although I doubt it. I do think the reason a lot of relationships fall apart is because people stop appreciating and cherishing their partner as itâ€™s no longer fun and exciting. Practicing gratitude towards oneâ€™s partner helps a lot with that. Sugar makes it easy because you never have to argue about housework, bills, childcare, etc.. Itâ€™s not â€œreal life.â€ Especially for those having affairs: itâ€™s an escape.
Youâ€™re missing my point. I take issue with the inherent inauthenticity of most SRs. Iâ€™m Canadian for godâ€™s sake, I encourage everyone to be kind and courteous always.

Dumping your shit on someone else is never appropriate. People do that because theyâ€™ve never learned emotional intelligence. This transcends sugar/vanilla and is not indicative of healthy, supportive relationships. Being on your best behaviour is to be distinguished from being genuine, supportive and thoughtful of oneâ€™s partner. Itâ€™s all about authenticity.
Well thatâ€™s pretty grim.

People are funny, arenâ€™t they? They want the â€œgoodâ€ parts of a relationship without the â€œbad.â€ But the â€œbadâ€ stuff is where people truly connect and understand one another, which in turn creates a stronger and more secure relationship. Without that, youâ€™re always going to be wondering.

Maybe try talking to her about it? When my SD shared his insecurities with me, it only further endeared him to me.

This is the problem I have with this lifestyle. Itâ€™s hard to find a genuine connection without constantly having a question mark in the back of your head. I had the utmost fortune to meet a man with whom I share a deep intellectual, emotional, and sexual bond - I havenâ€™t felt so cherished and respected by anyone since the man to whom I was formerly engaged. This will be my last SR.

The bowl is a funny place where people put on their best faces in exchange for something they desire (intimacy or money). It lacks the messiness of â€œrealâ€ relationships. But real human relationships ARE messy, and when you skip out on that you miss a whole level of vulnerability and connection that I find necessary for a fulfilling life: telling someone how you feel without being certain of the outcome; falling in love with someone you â€œshouldnâ€™tâ€/in spite of insurmountable obstacles; sharing your darkest fears, shame, and desires despite the risk of judgment; opening your heart to and truly being seen by someone. This messy, ugly, raw place is where we are truly alive. 

And I think a lot of SRs are missing that, which makes me sad. Most SDs are married and forced to live a secret life. I donâ€™t date married men anymore as a result of this; I donâ€™t like the idea of a woman being left in the dark as to her husbandâ€™s true desires, instead of him being honest and vulnerable with her in sharing what he really wants from his life and relationships. I donâ€™t like meeting in hotels and leaving before his â€œcurfew,â€ instead of having a drink on his back patio and falling asleep together in his bed. I value authenticity and honesty more than anything else in my relationships. 

Totally unwarranted monologue no one asked for, but I wanted to share my POV on the issue. To each his own.
